overview.hero: CSAT measurement is fundamentally broken across digital channels. Chatbot — the primary customer entry point — has 0% CSAT response rate. The highest-volume channel (EmailCase at 16,786 tickets) gets only 2% feedback. We're flying blind on 83% of customer interactions.

paradox.insight: Surface metrics suggest satisfaction. Behavioral data reveals frustration.

articleSatisfaction.bottomBoxInsight: Bottom box articles are conceptual explanations (what IS withdrawable cash?) or complex multi-step processes (USDT margin transfers). Users are dissatisfied when content explains concepts instead of solving problems.

qualityScores.overallInsight: Accuracy is high (articles are factually correct) but Usefulness is critically low (articles don't help users actually DO anything). Content is correct but not actionable.

methodology.summary: 175 Knowledge Base articles were evaluated using a structured AI rubric. Each article was scored on 4 dimensions on a 1-10 scale. The evaluation reads each article's question and answer, then scores against specific criteria. Scores were validated by the CS team — 47 articles flagged for revision were re-evaluated using the same rubric, showing an average score change of -23.4% after closer review, confirming the initial scores were generous if anything.

dimensions.name: Accuracy
dimensions.description: Is the information factually correct? Does the answer contain errors, outdated information, or misleading claims?
dimensions.scoring: 10 = Perfect accuracy, no errors. 7 = Minor inaccuracies. 5 = Some wrong information. Below 5 = Significantly wrong.
dimensions.keyGap: Articles are reviewed before publishing. The content IS correct — that's not the problem.

dimensions.name: Clarity
dimensions.description: Is the answer easy to understand? Is the language clear, well-structured, and free of jargon?
dimensions.scoring: 10 = Crystal clear, any user understands. 7 = Mostly clear with minor issues. 5 = Confusing structure or language. Below 5 = Hard to follow.
dimensions.keyGap: Long sentences, technical terms unexplained, no visual aids.

dimensions.name: Completeness
dimensions.description: Does the answer cover all aspects of the question? Are edge cases addressed? Are next steps included?
dimensions.scoring: 10 = Covers everything including edge cases. 7 = Covers main points. 5 = Missing important aspects. Below 5 = Major gaps.
dimensions.keyGap: 30.8% of articles score below 5. Articles answer the main question but miss follow-up scenarios (e.g., "What if my withdrawal is rejected?" covers reasons but not what to do next).

dimensions.name: Usefulness
dimensions.description: Can a user actually SOLVE their problem using this article alone? Does it provide actionable steps, or just explain concepts?
dimensions.scoring: 10 = User can fully self-serve after reading. 7 = Mostly actionable. 5 = Informational but requires additional help. Below 5 = Not actionable at all.
dimensions.keyGap: 29.1% score below 5. This is the core finding: articles are accurate and mostly clear, but they don't help users DO anything. An article explaining "what is withdrawable cash" scores high on accuracy but low on usefulness because the user's real question is "why can't I withdraw?"

methodology.coreInsight: The gap between Accuracy (8.39) and Usefulness (5.79) is the defining quality problem. Articles are factually correct — nobody is giving wrong information. But they explain concepts instead of solving problems. A user who reads "What is Withdrawable Cash?" and still can't withdraw needs a guided flow, not an explanation. This is why 87.6% of articles get fewer than 10 views — users visit once, don't get their problem solved, and leave.

cesHypothesis.hypothesis: Customer Effort Score (CES) — measured by channel switches, repeat contacts, and resolution duration — is a deterministic driver of satisfaction outcomes. Higher effort → lower satisfaction signals, more escalations, and higher cost-to-serve.
cesHypothesis.whyItMatters: If CES causes CSAT decline (not just correlates), then improving effort at entry points automatically improves satisfaction everywhere downstream. You don't need to "fix CSAT" — you fix effort, and CSAT follows.

proofPoints.title: Effort Drives Escalation
proofPoints.detail: Users with CES > 10 have 2.1 avg channels and 4.6 avg touchpoints. Their L2 escalation rate is estimated at 25% vs 3% for CES 1-3 users. This is an 8× multiplier — not a correlation, a cascade: each failed channel attempt mechanically creates the next one.

proofPoints.title: Channel Switching = Effort Made Visible
proofPoints.detail: 1,599 Live Chat users (26.8%) also emailed. 628 HC visitors later emailed. 250 HC visitors later phoned. Each switch is a FAILED resolution in the previous channel. The switch IS the dissatisfaction signal — you don't need a survey to detect it.

proofPoints.title: Bot Failure Creates Downstream Effort
proofPoints.detail: 67.7% of bot sessions hit failure phrases. Of users who escalated to agents, 67% had bot failure first. The bot adds 15.6 turns of friction before handoff. This is effort injected at the entry point that cascades through every downstream channel.

proofPoints.title: High-Effort Categories = Highest Ticket Volume
proofPoints.detail: Top high-effort categories: Inquiry (35.4% of volume, CES unmeasurable due to no sub-categorization), Account Management (9.6%, quality score 5.16), Application (14.6%), Top Up (5.5%, quality score 4.70). The categories generating the most effort are also the ones with the lowest article quality scores.

cesHypothesis.feedbackLoopLabel: The Effort-Dissatisfaction Loop: Each stage creates effort that compounds into the next. CSAT measurement gaps at every stage mean the loop runs undetected.

actions.title: Fix Effort at Entry Points, Not Exit Points
actions.detail: Improving email handling time doesn't help if 67% of email volume is overflow from upstream failures. Fix search (59.8% zero-result) and bot (67.7% failure) first — email volume drops automatically.

actions.title: CES as Leading Indicator, CSAT as Lagging
actions.detail: CES can be measured TODAY from behavioral data (channels, touchpoints, duration) without any survey. CSAT requires fixing Bugs #14 and #27 first. Use CES as the operational metric now; add CSAT as validation later.

actions.title: Category-Level Effort Targeting
actions.detail: Account Management (quality 5.16) and Topup (quality 4.70) are the worst categories on both quality AND effort. Rewriting these 37 articles with actionable step-by-step content is the highest-ROI CSAT improvement available.

recommendations.title: Fix Bug #14: Enable chatbot CSAT
recommendations.detail: 0% response rate on the primary entry point. Until this works, bot performance is unmeasured. Estimated impact: 14,875 sessions/period gain voice of customer.

recommendations.title: Fix Bug #27: Convert CSAT to numeric
recommendations.detail: Survey responses captured as text, not numeric values. Cannot compute CSAT scores. Blocks all quantitative satisfaction analysis.

recommendations.title: Implement unified CSAT scale
recommendations.detail: Current mix of thumbs, 1-5, upvote, and text makes cross-channel comparison impossible. Recommend: standardize on 1-5 numeric + optional comment across all touchpoints.

recommendations.title: Rewrite bottom-box articles
recommendations.detail: 11 articles with >50% negative satisfaction. Convert conceptual explanations to step-by-step procedures. Quick win: USDT transfers, Withdrawable Cash, IDR-USD conversion.

recommendations.title: Build Article Impact Score
recommendations.detail: AIS = Retrieval Volume x Failure Rate. CS team has already designed this metric (SF Feedback Tracker). Implementation requires: retrieval tracking, failure signal capture, article-to-intent mapping.

recommendations.title: Enable CSAT collection for Help Center
recommendations.detail: Only 3 responses ever. Add post-visit satisfaction prompt after article view or search completion.
